posts.author: KailPendragon
posts.content:
Go Druid 6/DwD 6/Shifter 8 preepic for +1 to all saves at no cost. Rather than getting a medium score in both Listen and Spot, you'd be better off maxing one skill only (and that implies delaying the last DwD lvl at least or even better spreading the lvl taken in epic to get regular skill dumps). Animal Empathy is even too high. Lore is generally speaking wasted points and I'd suggest getting some trap skills for added versatility and tactical options.

The starting ability spread is not good, you are spending too much on CON at the expense of everything else. Start Str 10, Dex 14, Con 18, Wis 14, Int 14, Cha 6. Using only the ability increases every 4 lvls you'll reach Wis 20 and get Con 22 for +40 HPs/+1 Fort and you'll have a higher Str (better carrying capacity unshifted) and Dex score (+1 AC, ranged AB for what matters and +1 Ref).

The concept is interesting, you might want to explore a heavier DwD version (say Druid 8/Shifter 10/DwD 22) and compare it to this one. I'm lately intrigued by Risen Lord builds and I still have a couple to post myself.

posts.author: HipMaestro
posts.content:
I also cringe at the overly-allocated CON level. Unless you are planning on spending most of your time unshifted it makes little sense since the RL form will set its own CON level @19 (and the fort save associated with it). Even if you simply reduced CON down to 12 or 14 the build would have loads of extra skill points to play with by boosting INT. I don't think EDR is really practical with shifter because of all the overrides. I would just do with the DR from DwD and let it go at that.

There are a few nuances about Risen Lord that seem to remain true on most servers (and Kail & others can surely correct me per their own experiences), but an average cleric will easily turn a RL or just Heal him once or twice and swat him with an enchanted newspaper to finish the job. I remember a particularly ugly encounter with my RL when I failed to notice a converging pack of duergar clerics whilst merrily dicing their friends and lasted a total of 5 secs once they had arrived within turning range. This means it is best to develop a secondary, high SR, reliable form, like Rak to deal with those situations. Druid caster vs. Cleric caster = smiling cleric, dead druid. Considering a secondary form may also help you to redistribute your abilities much more efficiently.

The other issue specifically about any undead shape is that heal potions do not work in combat, yet they work fine with all other forms (positive energy will not help undead). And since no items can be used while in shifted from, you must unshift, heal, then reshift. IIRC equipping regen items work (as does any sort of regen buff spell).

My main emphasis is: don't depend on a single form in every situation. It will disappoint you.

Be aware: all the feats related to weapon focus and proficiency are wasted on a shifter. None of them change the shifted AB at all. Unless you wanted to wield a scythe while unshifted, but why would you do that and get critted and sneak attacked? Epic prowess is one of the very few AB boost feats that will help a shifted form. Armor Skin also works as expected.

Since Monk is the most natural tertiary for shifter builds, utilizing both the WIS AC and unarmed progression, it will be a tough call where to throw the excess ability points using DwD. If it were me, I'd throw at least a few more into INT (and follow Kail's suggestion about developing some cross-class skill proficiency) unless you wanted to simply raise your druid caster DCs as high as possible. I prefer to play a shifter as a shifter rather than a convenient method to gain some melee presence. Druids casters are best at lvl 26 and higher. It's a tough decision IMHO.

posts.author: KailPendragon
posts.content:
HipMaestro wrote:

Be aware: all the feats related to weapon focus and proficiency are wasted on a shifter. None of them change the shifted AB at all. Unless you wanted to wield a scythe while unshifted, but why would you do that and get critted and sneak attacked? Epic prowess is one of the very few AB boost feats that will help a shifted form. Armor Skin also works as expected.
Hip, here I have to correct you. Only those weapon feats related to "unarmed" do not apply to unarmed shifted shapes (that happens because unarmed shapes are not technically unarmed but use creature weapons), and even then it's WF/EWF: Unarmed, WS/EWS: Unarmed and Devastating Critical: Unarmed not to work. Improved Critical: Unarmed works and Overwhelming Critical: Unarmed works too (no matter the fact it's pointless to get it). Epic Prowess, as you say, applies normally. Other AB boosts working are Druid's Nature Sense and Ranger's BoE.

So, summing up, all weapon feats related to actual melee weapons apply normally for armed shifted shapes, so Risen Lord will benefit AB wise from WF/EWF: Scythe and Kobold Commando will benefit from WF/EWF: Shortsword etc.
Formerly HipMaestro also wrote:I also cringe at the overly-allocated CON level. Unless you are planning on spending most of your time unshifted it makes little sense since the RL form will set its own CON level @19 (and the fort save associated with it). Even if you simply reduced CON down to 12 or 14 the build would have loads of extra skill points to play with by boosting INT. I don't think EDR is really practical with shifter because of all the overrides. I would just do with the DR from DwD and let it go at that.
EDR I-III stacks with DwD damage reduction for a grand total of 15/- damage reduction. This total score does not stack with 15/+3 of RL, but the best of the two (and consider that he reaches 15/- only at DwD 10) is applied so 15/+3 vs weapons up to +2 enchantment, and X/- vs +3 and better weapons. It might seem overkill for a damage soaker like RL, but I think that if someone is giving up Wis AC and classed tumble then he should get some other source of protection and EDR I-III qualifies for that. Have a look at my Graveyard Shifter build were I go for ED and EDR III to augment RL defensive nature.

Getting turned is definitely a big gripe. The moment you see a cleric, unshift.

I was able to confirm most of what Kail has described about the combat feats. Didn't test Improved Unarmed Strike (AoOs are just too tedious to test IMO.)but if Kail or others have, it would a good thing to know. Looks like I will be throwing the shifter guide I based all my builds upon into the trashcan where it belongs. Too bad Zelle's guide is no longer accessible If any guild member had the foresight to copy those threads, I think it would make a valuable addition to the guild's resources. I'd even be willing to distill all Zelle's versions down into a single parsed, compilation.

In any case, here are the results of my testing:

Feat Effects on Polymorph Forms: Shifters, vanilla NWN v1.69 (110730)

Shifted shapes tested, unarmed: wyrmling, harpy, manticore, iron golem

Shifted shape tested,armed/Weapon

Minotaur (pre-epic)/Battleaxe
Minotaur (epic)/Greataxe
Drider/Spear
Drow Warrior/Long sword
Lizardfolk/Whip
Commando/Short sword
Risen Lord/Scythe
Azer chief/Dwarven waraxe

Feat/Shifted Shape types/Effect

Improved Critical/Minotaur(both),Drider,Azer chief/Crit 19-20 x3
Improved Critical/Lizardfolk,unarmed/Crit 19-20 x2
Improved Critical/Risen Lord/Crit 19-20 x4
Improved Critical/Drow Warrior,Commando/Crit 17-20 x2

Weapon Focus/armed,unarmed/+1AB
Epic Weapon Focus/armed,unarmed/+2AB (stacks w/WF for +3AB)

Weapon Specialization/armed/+2 damage
Epic WS/armed/+4 damage (stacks w/WS for +6 damage)
Weapon Specialization/unarmed/no effect
Epic WS/unarmed/no effect

Therefore, the only change I would make to Kail's assessment is in regards to unarmed WF/EWF which do increase AB for all the unarmed forms I tested.

So, back to the build...

My own preference would be to drop the Exotic Proficiency, WF: Scythe & EWF: Scythe in favor of Improved Critical: Scythe (doesn't require Exotic Prof) and IKD. That leaves a free feat for either Mobility (+4AC vs. AoO) or Expertise (+5AC/-5AB). I like Expertise myself because in early levels, the wyrmling breath attack can be extremely effective plus is useful for a druid in casting mode.

The fact that Imp Crit works for all forms really changes my thinking about shifter builds in general since it is a combat advantage that has no prereqs. I will definitely give it more consideration in the future and with respect to this build, I would surely love a Risen Lord critting on twice as many hits as without it. PvP against other Risen Lords it would be worthless, but would be great for PvM applications.

To go slightly OT for a moment...

I am wondering if the above feats would have the same effects on non-shifter polymorphs, specifically the Iron Golem that arcane spellcasters use to get out of some sticky situations. Too tired from testing to check this right now, but it would be good to know nonetheless.

BTW, thanks D'Alessandro for posting this build so that my own shifter experience could be broadened.

All IC feats apply to shifted shapes, including unarmed. So IC: scythe works with RL, IC: longsword with drow and IC: unarmed with all unarmed shapes (which is the actual oddity since armed shapes use the relative weapon but unarmed ones use creature weapons and are hence not technically unarmed).

Some shapes also are affected by the size modifier (which the character sheet does neither show or compute): Minotaur is large (-1 AB/AC), Kobold Commando is small (+1 AB/AC) and Dragon is huge (-2 AB/AC) for example. Anyhow, everything is clear using combat debugging and checking the logs.

Actually, Kail, your information here is not entirely correct. I know you're just talking about size modifiers and I know that you know this as well, since it was you who taught me this bit, but to those with a little less knowledge than yourself or me, it may seem as if to find the correct AB in Dragon Shape you just take whatever the sheet shows you and subtract 2. So just to clarify to the readers here, the +6 Dragon claws aren't considered by the sheet either, so basically to find your AB / AC in Dragon Shape, you add 4 to (+6 from Dragon Claws, -2 from Size Modifier) and subtract 2 from the shown AC because of said Size Modifier. So AB/AC in DS = +4/-2 what is shown in your bugged Character Sheet.

And what the hell, since we are at it, to use combat debugging here is what you have to do: IN SINGLE PLAYER MODE ONLY.

- press ` to enable commands.
- type DebugMode 1 EXACTLY AS I DID here to enable cheats, you should receive a message that says: Success or something like that
- type the following command: dm_enablecombatdebugging
- type DebugMode 0 to disable cheats afterwards

I haven't done that in a while, so I'm not 100% sure this is how you do it, but it's either this or something very similar to it, do any of you by any chance remember enough to assert whether the procedure above is correct?

Take it EZ!

Actually, it's dm_enablecombatdebugging x, where x = 1 to turn the debugging log ON and x = 0, to turn it OFF.

You can also use the chat bar which I think is easier because you can use the mouse cursor to make corrections if you err. The same procedure is used. Just precede each command with two pound signs (##) in the char bar and no need to bring up a DOS prompt.

There is also a third option and that is to quick slot the chat commands (with the ##) into 4 quick slots if you have them available. That way you only need to do the typing once for a character and can toggle in and out of debugging mode with mouseclicks.
